title: How to Keep Your Shoes from Stinking

steps.title: Wear shoes that fit you.
steps.content: Wear shoes that fit you. When your shoes don't fit you, your feet could sweat more than usual (aside from being incredibly uncomfortable). Get fitted before buying shoes and don't be afraid to see a podiatrist if your feet begin to hurt you. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Wear shoes that have breathable fabrics.
steps.content: Wear shoes that have breathable fabrics. It's not a horribly revolutionary idea, but wearing shoes with more breathable fabrics will cut down on foot-sweat and odor. Synthetic fabrics usually do not breathe well. The most breathable fabrics include: [2] X Research source Cotton Linen Leather Hemp.

steps.title: Alternate shoes.
steps.content: Alternate shoes. Avoid wearing the same pair of shoes two days in a row. This gives them a chance to air out before you wear again. [3] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: Give your shoes a nice airing out.
steps.content: Give your shoes a nice airing out. Your feet need airing up, but so do your shoes. When it's nice and sunny outside, don't hesitate to let your shoes play outside—without you. That's it––give them a nice break!

steps.title: Give shoes the boot.
steps.content: Give shoes the boot. Banish smelly shoes to the car in winter. Leave them out there over a couple of freezing days and nights. Allow them to warm slowly to room temperature before wearing.

steps.title: Wash your feet every day or every other day with soap.
steps.content: Wash your feet every day or every other day with soap. If fungus or bacteria is what's causing your feet and shoes to smell, it's a good idea to attack the smell at the source. Every day when taking a shower, give both of your feet a good, sudsy wipe-down with soap. [4] X Research source Washing your feet every day with soap may dry them out and leave them cracked. If they get dry, moisturize them with after washing and consider washing every other day.

steps.title: Put deodorant on your feet.
steps.content: Put deodorant on your feet. This might sound weird, but keep in mind that your feet sweat too. Buy a stick of deodorant that is meant only for your feet (that is, don't use it anywhere else) and apply it every morning. [5] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: Put baby powder or Gold Bond on your feet.
steps.content: Put baby powder or Gold Bond on your feet. Then cover up with socks. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Put another layer of baby powder in the shoes.
steps.content: Put another layer of baby powder in the shoes. Then wear the shoes. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Deodorize with baking soda.
steps.content: Deodorize with baking soda. Sprinkle a bit into your shoes every night when you take them off. Before you put your shoes on in the morning, take the shoes outside and clap the soles together to get rid of excess powder. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Freeze out the smell.
steps.content: Freeze out the smell. Put your shoes in freezer-size sealable plastic bags (one per shoe, if necessary) and put them in the freezer overnight. The cold should kill any fungus or bacteria causing the odor.

steps.title: Wear socks when possible.
steps.content: Wear socks when possible. Breathable cotton socks help absorb some of the moisture from your feet, keeping your shoes a bit cleaner. [9] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source If you're wearing flats or high heels, you can wear socks that won't show. They should be cut so that they only cover the back of your heel, the sides and bottom of your feet, and the front of your toes. Use running socks. They apply "moisture-wicking" technology which helps to keep your feet dry.

steps.title: Use cedar insoles or chips.
steps.content: Use cedar insoles or chips. Cedar has anti-fungal properties and is often used to deodorize clothes. The insoles would stay in your shoes, while the chips would need to be inserted at night and removed in the morning. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Put in odor-control insoles.
steps.content: Put in odor-control insoles. Odor-controlling insoles can be cut to fit the shape of your sole, and come in several different colors. These work well for sandals, high heels or open-toed shoes. [11] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Secure the insole with small strips of double-sided tape or dabs of rubber cement. These will help the insole stay in place while keeping it easily removable.

steps.title: Use silver shoe linings.
steps.content: Use silver shoe linings. Linings containing silver are anti-microbial and can inhibit the growth of odor-causing bacteria.

steps.title: Use dryer sheets.
steps.content: Use dryer sheets. Simply place a couple of dryer sheets in your shoes while you use them. These instantly deodorize the smell.

steps.title: If your shoes are washable, give them a bath.
steps.content: If your shoes are washable, give them a bath. Either toss them in the washing machine or submerge them in a detergent bath for a gentler clean. Be sure to clean the inside, especially, (the insole, too) and let all the parts of the shoe dry before using again. For delicate shoes, wipe off as much dirt as you can with water and mild laundry detergent. [12] X Expert Source Rio Jongsae Kim Designer Shoe & Bag Care Specialist Expert Interview. 15 April 2021. Always let your shoes air dry. [13] X Expert Source Rio Jongsae Kim Designer Shoe & Bag Care Specialist Expert Interview. 15 April 2021.
